verses.text: This is what the LORD said to me: “Go and buy yourself a linen waistband and put it around your waist, but do not put it in water.”
verses.comment: The linen waistband (or 'loincloth') is a direct symbol representing Israel's close call to holiness set apart by God (cf. Ex. 28:39-42). The command not to wash it signifies the unwashed, unrepentant state of the people.

verses.text: So I bought a waistband according to the word of the LORD, and put it around my waist.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s obedient response shows his role as a prophet enacting God’s message.

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to me a second time:
verses.comment: A recurring pattern in prophecy, God often instructs his prophets in stages to deliver a symbolic act (see Ezek. 4:1–3).

verses.text: “Take the waistband which you have bought, which is around your waist, and go now to the Euphrates and hide it there in a crevice of the rock.”
verses.comment: The Euphrates, being far away, may point toward exile in Babylon (cf. Jer. 51:63) and the hidden or buried state of Israel's spiritual vocation.

verses.text: So I went and hid it by the Euphrates, as the LORD commanded me.
verses.comment: Jeremiah’s act is literal and dramatizes obedience to God's word, prefiguring Israel’s removal from the promised land.

verses.text: After many days, the LORD said to me, “Arise, go to the Euphrates, and take from there the waistband which I commanded you to hide there.”
verses.comment: The delay (‘after many days’) sets up Israel’s future suffering and loss of nearness to God through sin.

verses.text: So I went to the Euphrates and dug up the waistband and, behold, it was ruined; it was good for nothing.
verses.comment: The ruined loincloth visually confirms Israel and Judah’s spiritual decay. Compare to Isaiah 64:6 ('all our righteous deeds are like a polluted garment').

verses.text: Then the word of the LORD came to me:
verses.comment: Transition to God’s interpretation of the enacted sign. God explains the meaning of the symbol for His people.

verses.text: This is what the LORD says: 'In the same way I will ruin the pride of Judah and the great pride of Jerusalem.'
verses.comment: Pride is consistently condemned as causing separation from God (cf. Jas 4:6). Judah’s pride prevents repentance and relationship.

verses.text: These evil people, who refuse to listen to my words, who walk in the stubbornness of their hearts, and follow other gods to serve and worship them, will be like this waistband, which is good for nothing.
verses.comment: Idolatry is described as the root of Israel’s failure. Spiritually, to be useful one must remain pure and submitted to God, a recurring theme in purification and sanctification found throughout Scripture.

verses.text: For as the waistband clings to the waist of a man, so I made the whole house of Israel and the whole house of Judah cling to me—declares the LORD—to be for me a people, a name, a praise, and a glory. But they would not listen.”
verses.comment: God’s design for his people is intimacy and communion (cf. Ex. 19:5–6; 1 Pet 2:9). Spiritual interpretation: this foreshadows the New Covenant community united to God in Christ.

verses.text: “So you shall speak to them this word: 'This is what the LORD, the God of Israel, says: Every jar will be filled with wine.' And when they say to you, 'Do you not surely know that every jar will be filled with wine?'
verses.comment: The image of jars filled with wine prefigures judgment (Jer. 25:15); wine can symbolize both blessing (Ps. 104:15) and wrath (Rev. 14:10).

verses.text: Then you shall say to them, 'This is what the LORD says: Behold, I am about to fill all the inhabitants of this land—the kings who sit on David’s throne, the priests, the prophets, and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem—with drunkenness.'
verses.comment: The 'drunkenness' here symbolizes God’s coming judgment and confusion (cf. Ps. 75:8). Notably, the judgment falls on king, priest, prophet, and common people—indicating the unity and responsibility of the entire covenant people under their leaders.

verses.text: 'And I will dash them, one against another, fathers and sons together,' declares the LORD. 'I will not pity, nor spare, nor have compassion, that I might not destroy them.'
verses.comment: God’s mercy is withheld in the face of persistent unrepentance, showing the seriousness of the people’s rebellion—but not in contradiction to His mercy, for repentance is always necessary (cf. Luke 13:3).

verses.text: Hear and pay attention! Do not be proud, for the LORD has spoken.
verses.comment: A direct connection to the theme of humility—a key virtue in all spiritual growth. Throughout the Bible, pride leads to a fall (Prov. 16:18).

verses.text: Give glory to the LORD your God before he brings darkness, and before your feet stumble on the dark mountains. While you look for light, He turns it into deep shadow and makes it thick darkness.
verses.comment: Glory must first and foremost go to God. Spiritual darkness is the result of ongoing sin and rejection (cf. John 12:35).

verses.text: But if you will not listen, my soul will weep in secret for your pride; my eyes will weep bitterly and run down with tears, because the LORD’s flock will be taken captive.
verses.comment: Jeremiah expresses deep compassion, echoing Jesus who weeps over Jerusalem (Luke 19:41). Shepherd imagery (“the LORD’s flock”) points to divine leadership and care for the people.

verses.text: Say to the king and the queen mother, 'Come down from your thrones, for your beautiful crowns have fallen from your heads.'
verses.comment: The accountability of both king and queen mother reflects the importance of leadership within the people of God (cf. 2 Kings 24:8, 12, 15).

verses.text: The cities of the Negev are shut up, and there is no one to open them. All Judah is taken into exile, wholly taken into exile.
verses.comment: Full exile fulfills warnings of covenant curses for unfaithfulness in Deuteronomy 28:41.

verses.text: Lift up your eyes and see those who come from the north. Where is the flock that was given to you, your beautiful sheep?
verses.comment: The enemy 'from the north' refers to Babylon. Imagery of lost sheep is picked up by Christ in His parable of the lost sheep (Luke 15:3–7).

verses.text: What will you say when he sets as head over you those whom you yourself have taught to be your friends? Will not pangs seize you like those of a woman in labor?
verses.comment: Foreign rulers raised up over them is the consequence of faithlessness; labor pains signify sudden, unavoidable suffering.

verses.text: And if you say in your heart, 'Why have these things come upon me?'—it is for the greatness of your iniquity that your skirts are lifted up and your heels exposed.
verses.comment: Unfaithfulness is described with the shame of exposure, symbolic of covenant breaking.

verses.text: Can an Ethiopian change his skin or a leopard his spots? Then also you can do good who are accustomed to doing evil.
verses.comment: This verse teaches about humanity’s need for transformation—a foreshadowing of the new heart and spirit promised in Ezekiel (Ezek. 36:26) and fulfilled in Christ through grace.

verses.text: I will scatter them like chaff blown away by the wind from the desert.
verses.comment: Chaff imagery is used throughout Scripture to contrast the righteous and wicked. Jesus also uses this in Matt. 3:12 in reference to final judgment.

verses.text: This is your lot, the portion I have measured out to you, declares the LORD, because you have forgotten me and trusted in lies.
verses.comment: God’s justice is evidenced in His perfect allocation of consequences—forgetting God and believing lies leads to spiritual destruction. The idea of God measuring portions calls to mind both judgment and blessing (cf. Ps. 16:5–6).

verses.text: Therefore I will also lift up your skirts over your face, and your shame will be seen.
verses.comment: Exposure of nakedness is used as a metaphor for public shame due to sin (cf. Isa. 47:3). Compare to Revelation 3:18 where the church is counseled to clothe itself in righteousness.

verses.text: Your adulteries, your lustful neighings, the lewdness of your prostitution, on the hills in the fields—I have seen your abominations. Woe to you, Jerusalem! How long will you remain unclean?
verses.comment: Spiritual adultery is idolatry—departing from true worship. This verse’s lamentation forms both a warning and a call to repentance and purification, themes fulfilled finally and perfectly in Christ, who purifies His people (Eph. 5:25–27).
